questions.text: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his parents after sustaining a fracture from a minor fall while playing. On physical examination, he appears smaller than his peers for his age. Notably, he has blue sclera, and his medical history reveals multiple previous fractures that occurred with minimal trauma. What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?
questions.solution:
Osteogenesis Imperfecta (Fragilitas Ossium, Vrolik's Disease)

Overview: Osteogenesis Imperfecta (OI) is a genetic condition characterized by a tendency for frequent fractures due to weak and brittle bones. It arises from defective collagen synthesis, affecting not only bones but also other collagen-containing tissues such as skin, sclera, teeth, and ligaments.

Genetics and Inheritance:

  • Autosomal Dominant: Most common form of inheritance.
  • Autosomal Recessive: A severe variant that leads to early death, typically within a few years.

Clinical Features:

  • Frequent Fractures: Occur usually with minimal trauma.
  • Blue Sclera: A hallmark sign.
  • Joint Laxity: Increased flexibility of the joints.
  • Otosclerosis: May occur in adulthood, leading to hearing impairment.

Disease Progression:

  • Severe Type: Patients typically do not survive beyond early childhood.
  • Mild Type: Individuals live a normal lifespan but experience frequent fractures throughout life.

Bone Healing and Deformities:

  • Fractures usually heal normally, but malunion can lead to deformities or joint contractures.
  • The tendency for fractures often decreases with age.

Option A - Rickets is not associated with ocular manifestation.

Option B - Scurvy:

  • It is associated with Vit-C deficiency which is associated with defect in collagen cross-linking.
  • This is associated with primitive collagen formation throughout the blood vessel: Leads to haemorrhage: Pseudoparalysis: Highly painful limbs with subperiosteal haemorrhage.
  • Mx of Scurvy: 25mg/day for Infants, 30-40 mg/day for children, 40-75 mg/day for adults.

Option D - Battered baby syndrome:

  • Soft tissue injury > Bony fractures, Fractures in different stage of healing.
  • Most imp: History taking
  • In a case study of 33 patients, Patients of OI were diagnosed incorrectly as battered baby.

Reference. Tachdjian's Pediatric Orthopaedics: 6th edition page number: 1154, 1944, 1946, 1947.

Reference: J. Maheshwari's 5th Edition of Essential Orthopaedics page number. 316.

questions.text: 66-year-old female complaints of pain in bilateral knee. The pain increases after prolonged walking and cross legged sitting. She also complains of friction sound coming from her both knee joints. The X-ray shows bilateral reduced joint space and osteophytes. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A and B

Radiological features of OA knee are:

Narrowing of joint space, often limited to a part of the joint e.g., may be limited to medial compartment of tibio-femoral joint of the knee.

  • Subchondral sclerosis – dense bone under the articular surface
  • Subchondral cysts
  • Osteophyte formation
  • Loose bodies
  • Deformity of the joint (usually genu varus)

Fig. Osteoarthritic changes in knee joint

Option C – Ankylosing spondylitis usually affects SI joints and Spine causing pain and stiffness. Xray shows characteristic Bamboo spine appearance.

Fig. Bamboo spine in Ankylosing Spondylitis

Option D - Heamophilic arthropathy involves history of bleeding disorders and frequent heamarthrosis and swelling of joint following minor trauma.

Fig. Hemophilic arthropathy in Knee joint

Reference: J. Maheshwari's 5th Edition of Essential Orthopaedics page number. 296, 300.

questions.text: All of the following are radiological features seen in rickets except:
questions.solution:
Radiological Features of Rickets

Radiological signs of rickets are typically first observed in the lower ends of the radius and ulna. To screen a patient suspected of having rickets, antero-posterior X-rays of both wrists and knees are commonly used.

Key radiological features include:

  1. Delayed Appearance of Epiphyses (Option B)
    • The normal development of epiphyseal ossification is delayed.
  2. Widening of the Epiphyseal Plates
    • The normal width of the epiphyseal plate is 2-4 mm. In rickets, this width is increased due to the excessive accumulation of uncalcified osteoid at the growth plate.
  3. Cupping of the Metaphysis (Option A)
    • In normal bones, the metaphysis meets the epiphyseal plate with a smooth line of sclerosis (known as the zone of provisional calcification).
    • In rickets, this line is absent, and the metaphyseal end appears irregular.
  4. Splaying of the Metaphysis (Option D)
    • The metaphyseal ends are splayed due to pressure from accumulating cartilage cells at the growth plate.
  5. Rarefaction of the Diaphysial Cortex
    • This occurs in the later stages of the disease, resulting in thinning of the bone cortex.
  6. Bone Deformities:
    • Common deformities seen in older children include:
      • Knock knees
      • Bow legs
      • Coxa vara (a deformity of the hip)

Option C - Looser's zone are seen in osteomalacia. These are radiolucent zones occurring at sites of stress. Common sites are the pubic rami, axillary border of scapula, ribs and the medial cortex of the neck of the femur.

Reference: J. Maheshwari's 5th Edition of Essential Orthopaedics page number: 311.

questions.text: A 44 year old man presents with complain of low back pain for 3 months. His MRI image is given below. Which structure of vertebrae is affected in this condition ?
questions.solution:
Spondylolisthesis

Definition: Spondylolisthesis is the forward displacement of a vertebra over the one below it. It most commonly occurs between the L5-S1 and L4-L5 vertebrae. Displacement can also occur backward, known as retrolisthesis.

Pathology

  • Normal Mechanism: Forward displacement is typically prevented by:
    • Engagement of the vertebral body's articular processes with those of the adjacent vertebra.
    • Attachments of intervertebral discs and ligaments, which provide limited resistance.
  • Defects in the Mechanism: Any defect in this stabilizing mechanism can lead to spondylolisthesis.

Types of Spondylolisthesis:

  1. Isthmic (Most Common Type)
    • Lesion in the pars interarticularis. Three subtypes:
      • Lytic: Fatigue fracture of the pars interarticularis. (Option A)
      • Intact but elongated: Pars interarticularis is intact but elongated.
      • Acute fracture: Sudden fracture of the pars interarticularis.
    • Results in the anterior half of the vertebra slipping forward while the posterior half remains with the lower vertebra.
  2. Dysplastic (Least Common Type)
    • Congenital abnormality leading to vertebrae slipping over one another.
  3. Degenerative
    • Common in the elderly. Caused by instability of posterior facet joints due to osteoarthritis, leading to subluxation.
    • Displacement may be mild, with rare neurological disturbances.
  4. Pathological
    • Results from generalized or localized bone diseases that weaken the articulation between vertebrae.
  5. Traumatic (Very Rare Type)
    • Occurs due to injury, resulting in one vertebra slipping over another.

Reference: J. Maheshwari's 5th Edition of Essential Orthopaedics page number: 283.

questions.text: Sunlight is required at which step in metabolism of Vitamin D in our body?
questions.solution:
Vitamin D and Its Metabolism

Forms of Vitamin D:

  • Endogenous Form:
    • Cholecalciferol (Vitamin D3): Produced in the skin from cholesterol metabolism (7-dehydrocholesterol) under ultraviolet radiation/ sunlight. (Option A)
  • Exogenous Forms:
    • D2 (Ergocalciferol): Obtained from dietary sources.
    • D3 (Cholecalciferol): Usually the form supplemented in diets.

Activation Steps:

  • Hydroxylation Process:
    • First Step (25-hydroxylation): Occurs in the liver, converting Vitamin D2 and D3 to 25-hydroxyvitamin D (calcidiol).
    • Second Step (1-hydroxylation): Takes place in the kidneys, converting 25-hydroxyvitamin D to 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D (calcitriol), the active form (Option D).

Functions of Active Vitamin D:

  • Calcium Absorption:
    • 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D stimulates intestinal absorption of calcium.
  • Bone Health:
    • Acts on bone tissue to support bone matrix calcification, though the precise role in bone metabolism remains controversial. Adequate amounts of calcium and vitamin D metabolites are essential for effective calcification.

Control of Action:

  • Intestinal Calcium Absorption:
    • The primary physiological action of 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D is to increase the intestinal absorption of calcium.
  • Bone Calcification:
    • Small amounts of vitamin D metabolites are necessary, in conjunction with sufficient calcium, for proper calcification of the bone matrix.

Reference:J. Maheshwari's 5th Edition of Essential Orthopaedics page number. 310.

choices.text: Young males are more commonly affected

questions.text: A 28-year-old male presents with chronic back pain and stiffness, which is worse in the morning and improves with exercise. Physical examination reveals tenderness over the sacroiliac joints, and further investigations confirm the diagnosis of ankylosing spondylitis. Which of the following statements about ankylosing spondylitis is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Option B - Dilated cardiomyopathy is not typically associated with ankylosing spondylitis. However, other cardiac complications like aortitis and conduction abnormalities can occur. The rest of the options are correct.

Clinical Features of Ankylosing Spondylitis

  1. Presenting Complaints:
    • Affects young adults (15-30 years), more common in males (M= 10:1) (Option D)
    • Classic presentation:
      • Gradual onset of lower back pain and stiffness.
      • Pain worsens at night/early morning, improves with movement.
      • Pain may also affect the heel, pubic symphysis, manubrium sterni, and costo-sternal joints.
      • Advanced stages show kyphotic spinal deformity and hip deformities.
    • Unusual presentations:
      • Peripheral joint involvement (shoulders, hips, knees).
      • May be associated with chronic inflammatory bowel disease.
  2. Examination Findings:
    • Gait: Straight, stiff back with possible diffuse kyphosis.
    • Stiff spine: Loss of lumbar lordosis, limited lumbar flexion.
  3. HLA B27 is usually positive (Option C)

Extra-Articular Manifestations:

  1. Ocular: (Option A)
    • 25% of patients experience acute iritis, with potential for recurrent episodes leading to iris scarring and depigmentation.
  2. Cardiovascular: (Option B)
    • Long-standing disease can cause aortic incompetence, cardiomegaly, conduction defects, and pericarditis.
  3. Neurological:
    • Risk of atlanto-axial subluxation, cervical spine fractures, and spinal cord compression from minor trauma.
  4. Pulmonary:
    • Painless thoracic cage restriction due to costo-vertebral joint involvement.
    • Possible bilateral apical lobe fibrosis, resembling tuberculosis on X-ray.
  5. Systemic:
    • Generalized osteoporosis is common.
    • Occasionally, amyloidosis may develop.

Reference: J. Maheshwari's 5th Edition of Essential Orthopaedics page number: 291.

choices.text: Low back pain is the commonest clinical feature
Bisphosphonates are the treatment of choice

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman presents with a history of low back pain and a recent wrist fracture following a minor fall. She reports no history of major trauma. The physician suspects post-menopausal osteoporosis and orders a bone mineral density test. Which of the following statements regarding osteoporosis is incorrect?
questions.solution:
• Osteoporosis is diagnosed using the T-score from a bone mineral density (BMD) test, not the Z-score (Option C). The T-score compares a patient's bone density to that of a healthy young adult. Z-scores are used in specific cases, such as in younger patients, to compare with age-matched controls. The rest of the options are correct:
    • Option A - Osteoporosis typically shows normal alkaline phosphatase and calcium levels.
    • Option B - Low back pain is a common clinical feature due to vertebral fractures.
    • Option D - Bisphosphonates are commonly prescribed to prevent bone loss.

Reference: Miller's review of Orthopaedics 8th edition page number: 85.

questions.text: Which of the following hormones plays a primary role in regulating serum calcium levels in the body?
questions.solution:
Hypercalcemia

Manifestations:

  • Symptoms:
    • Polyuria, polydipsia, nephrolithiasis
    • CNS: confusion, stupor, weakness
    • GI: constipation, anorexia, nausea, vomiting, dehydration, muscle weakness

Causes:

  • Primary Hyperparathyroidism: (Option A)
    • PTH overproduction (usually due to adenoma)
    • Increases plasma calcium, decreases phosphate
    • Increased osteoclastic resorption

Diagnosis:

  • Laboratory Findings:
    • Elevated serum calcium, PTH, urinary phosphate
    • Decreased serum phosphate
  • Bony Changes:
    • Osteopenia, osteitis fibrosa cystica, brown tumors, chondrocalcinosis
  • Radiographic Findings:
    • Osteopenic bones, fractures, shaggy trabeculae, radiolucent areas
  • Histologic Changes:
    • Active osteoblasts and osteoclasts, wide osteoid seams

Other Causes:

  • Familial syndromes, pituitary adenomas (MEN types I & II), malignancy (most common), hyperthyroidism, vitamin D intoxication, prolonged immobilization, kidney disease, sarcoidosis.

Treatment:

  • Hydration (saline diuresis), loop diuretics, dialysis (for severe cases), mobilization, specific drugs (bisphosphonates, mithramycin, calcitonin, gallium nitrate).

Reference: Miller's review of Orthopaedics 8th edition page number: 63, 73.

choices.text: Elevated Calcium level, normal ALP, normal phosphate
Elevated Calcium level, elevated ALP, low phosphase
Normal Calcium, elevated ALP, elevated phosphate
Normal Calcium, normal ALP, normal phosphate

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman visits her primary care physician for a routine check-up. She has a history of osteoporosis and is concerned about her bone health. The physician orders a series of blood tests to evaluate her bone metabolism. Choose the correct option.
questions.solution:
Radiological Features of Osteoporosis

  • Decreased Bone Mass:
    • Radiological evidence of decreased bone mass is more reliable; however, about 30% of the bone mass must be lost before it becomes apparent on X-rays.

Key X-ray Features:

  1. Loss of Vertebral Height:
    • Collapse of vertebrae leading to a reduction in vertical height.
  2. Cod Fish Appearance:
    • The intervertebral disc bulges into adjacent vertebral bodies, creating a biconvex shape.
  3. Ground Glass Appearance:
    • A characteristic appearance of bones, especially noticeable in the pelvis.
  4. Singh's Index:
    • Developed by Singh et al., this index grades osteoporosis into 6 grades based on the trabecular pattern of the femoral neck trabeculae. (Details are outside the scope of this book.)
  5. Metacarpal Index and Vertebral Index:
    • Other methods for quantifying osteoporosis.

Laboratory Tests:

  • Biochemistry:
    • Serum calcium, phosphates, and alkaline phosphatase levels are typically within normal limits. (Options A,B,C and D)
    • Total plasma proteins and plasma albumin may be low.

Quantification Methods:

  1. Densitometry:
    • A method to quantify osteoporosis by measuring the absorption of photons (from gamma-emitting isotopes) by bone calcium.
    • Two types available:
      • Ultrasound-based
      • X-ray based
    • DEXA Scan:
      • An X-ray based bone densitometry method considered the gold standard in quantifying bone mass.
  2. Neutron Activation Analysis:
    • Involves activating calcium in the bone through neutron bombardment and measuring its activity.
  3. Bone Biopsy:
    • Another investigative method used to assess bone health.

Reference: J. Maheshwari's 5th Edition of Essential Orthopaedics page number: 309.

questions.text: A 22 year old male suffering from scoliosis was advised deformity correction surgery. The surgery was performed as seen in the image below. In the given spine straightening surgery, the screws are fixed to which part of the vertebra?
questions.solution:
Treatment of Scoliosis

  1. Observation
    • Indications:
      • Skeletally immature patients with curves less than 20-25 degrees.
      • Skeletally mature patients with curves less than 45 degrees.
  2. Bracing
    • Goal:
      • To halt or slow curve progression in skeletally immature patients. Bracing does not reverse the curve.
    • Indications:
      • Curves greater than 25 degrees or 20 degrees with documented progression.
    • Types of Braces:
      • Milwaukee Brace: Cervicothoracolumbosacral orthosis (CTLSO); rarely used.
      • Boston Underarm Thoracolumbosacral (TLSO) Orthosis:
        • Suitable for curves with the apex at T8 or below.
        • Note: Thoracic lordosis or hypokyphosis is a relative contraindication.
    • Effectiveness:
      • Bracing is less effective in boys and overweight patients.
      • Some experts recommend wearing the brace for 18 hours/day in patients at Risser stage 0.
      • Effectiveness is "dose dependent":
        • 90% effective when worn for more than 12-13 hours/day.
  3. Surgery
    • Goals:
      • Prevent curve progression and achieve solid fusion.
      • Obtain and maintain correction in the coronal, axial, and sagittal planes while avoiding complications.
    • Techniques:
      • Posterior Instrumentation and Fusion:
        • Segmental instrumentation with pedicle screws (most common), hooks, or wires connected to rods. (Option C)
        • Pullout strength can be increased by:
        • Correction of deformity and arthrodesis (fusion).
      • Anterior Instrumentation and Fusion:
        • Less common as a single approach, but useful in certain cases:
          • Single thoracic fusion (especially if hypokyphosis is present and if fusion levels can be preserved).
          • Single thoracolumbar/lumbar fusion.
    • Indications for Combined Approaches:
      • Very young patients: Triradiate cartilage open; used to prevent crankshaft phenomenon.
      • Large or stiff curves: To improve flexibility, usually for curves greater than 75 degrees. The use of pedicle screws and posterior osteotomies may make this unnecessary.

Reference: Miller's review of Orthopaedics 8th edition page number: 619.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents to the outpatient department with complaints of chronic back pain, stiffness, and a lack of spinal extension. An X-ray shows characteristic findings. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ankylosing Spondylitis:

  • Definition:
    • Ankylosing spondylitis (AS) is a chronic progressive inflammatory seronegative spondyloarthropathy.
  • Common Joint Involved:
    • Sacroiliac joint > spine.
  • Demographics:
    • Common in young males aged 15-40 years (Male to Female ratio: 10:1).
  • Genetic Marker:
    • HLA B27 positive in more than 90% of cases.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Morning stiffness relieved by activity.
    • Increased risk of acute spinal fractures, particularly in the cervical spine (C5-C6 and C6-C7 levels).
  • Clinical Tests:
    • SI side-to-side compression test
    • Gaenslen's test
    • Pump handle test
    • Patrick test
  • X-ray Signs:
    • Bilateral symmetrical sacroiliitis
    • Bamboo spine
    • Squaring of vertebrae
    • Syndesmophytes
  • Treatment:
    • NSAIDs (Indomethacin is commonly used)
    • TNF inhibitors

Reference: J. Maheshwari's 5th Edition of Essential Orthopaedics page number. 291.

questions.text: A 65-year-old postmenopausal female presents with a persistent backache that has not responded to conservative treatment. She reports a history of lifting a heavy weight 4 months ago, followed by progressively increasing pain that worsens with walking and while climbing stairs. The pain radiates down her legs after walking about 100 meters. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Lumbar Canal Stenosis (LCS) and Neurogenic Claudication

Key Feature: Neurogenic Claudication

  • Definition:
    • The hallmark of lumbar canal stenosis (LCS) is neurogenic claudication, characterized by pain originating in the lower back and radiating down the buttock, thigh, leg, and foot, especially during prolonged physical activity.
  • Pain Characteristics:
    • Worsens with standing or walking.
    • Relieved by bending forward (trunk flexion) or sitting.
    • Posture-related pain:
      • The central canal space decreases with axial loading and extension, leading to pain.
      • Canal space increases with axial distraction and flexion, reducing pain.

Posture and Pain Relief:

  • Flexion Posture Relief:
    • Patients experience relief when lying on their side (flexed posture) compared to lying flat.
  • Activities Relieving Pain:
    • Walking uphill and pushing a shopping cart provide relief (referred to as the positive shopping cart sign).
  • Characteristic Posture:
    • Due to the need to remain stooped forward to relieve neural pressure, the patient’s posture is described as "ape-like."

Clinical Examination:

  • Straight Leg Raising Test and Neurological Examination:
    • These tests are typically normal in patients with lumbar canal stenosis.

Diagnostic Confirmation:

  • CT Scan:
    • Diagnosis is confirmed by measuring the diameter of the spinal canal.
    • A canal diameter of less than 10 mm is diagnostic for LCS.

Differential Diagnosis:

  • Vascular Claudication: (Option D)
    • An important differential diagnosis for LCS is vascular claudication (pain caused by peripheral artery disease).
    • Key differentiator:
      • Pain that occurs with standing alone is more indicative of neurogenic claudication, whereas vascular claudication typically does not worsen with standing alone.

Option A - Pain in osteoporotic vertebreal compression fracture is localised to the vertebral region that has got compressed. Moreover the pain will gradually decrease over time.

Option C - Atherosclerosis is less likely to cause back or limb pain. It has more cardiac implications.

Reference: Miller's review of Orthopaedics 8th edition page number. 1715.

choices.text: Can be associated with pneumonitis and vasculitis
Swan neck and Boutonniere deformity are characteristic

questions.text: All of the following are true with respect to RA except :
questions.solution:
Deformities associated with RA are:


Clinical Features of Rheumatoid Arthritis

  • Age of Onset:
    • Typically occurs between 20 to 50 years of age.
  • Gender Predisposition:
    • Women are affected 3 times more commonly than men.

Common Presentations:

  1. Acute, Symmetrical Polyarthritis:
    • Pain and stiffness in multiple joints (affecting at least four joints), particularly in the morning (Option A), marking the early stage of the disease.
    • Articular inflammation often follows.
    • The most commonly affected joints are the metacarpophalangeal joints, especially the index finger. (Option D)
  2. Fever of Unknown Origin (PUO):
    • Fever may be the initial symptom, especially in children, with no clear underlying cause.
  3. Visceral Manifestations:
    • Pneumonitis, rheumatoid nodules, and other visceral symptoms may precede joint complaints.
  4. Severe Muscle Spasm:
    • Muscle spasms may occur, limiting the range of motion in the joints.
  5. Joint Deformity (Later Stages):
    • Subluxation or dislocation of joints may occur as the disease progresses.
  6. Systemic Signs:
    • Fever, rash, and signs of systemic vasculitis may accompany the disease.
    • The rash is typically non-pruritic and maculopapular, affecting the face, trunk, and extremities.

Extra-Articular Manifestations of Rheumatoid Arthritis:

Option C - Although primarily a chronic polyarthritis, extra-articular manifestations are common and can significantly affect the prognosis of the disease. These may include:

  • Pulmonary involvement (pneumonitis)
  • Rheumatoid nodules
  • Systemic vasculitis

Investigations for Rheumatoid Arthritis:

  1. Radiological Examination:
    • X-rays of both hands and affected joints reveal the following features:
      • Reduced joint space
      • Erosion of articular margins
      • Subchondral cysts
      • Juxta-articular rarefaction
      • Soft tissue shadow at the joint level (due to joint effusion or synovial hypertrophy)
      • Deformities of the hand and fingers
  2. Blood Tests:
    • Elevated ESR (Erythrocyte Sedimentation Rate) (Option B)
    • Low hemoglobin
    • Rheumatoid Factor (RF):
      • An autoantibody directed against the Fc fragment of immunoglobulin G (IgG).
      • RF can belong to various classes (IgG, IgM, IgA, IgE), but the most commonly detected is IgM-RF.

Reference: J. Maheshwari's 5th Edition of Essential Orthopaedics page number. 287.

questions.text: Spinal injury with no radiological finding is commonly seen in:
questions.solution:
Spinal Cord Injury Without Radiographic Abnormality (SCIWORA)

  • Definition:
    • SCIWORA is a condition characterized by spinal cord injury, either complete or incomplete, in the absence of any radiographic abnormalities on X-ray or CT scans.
  • First Described By:
    • Pang and Wilberger.

Key Features:

  • MRI Findings:
    • In about 50% of cases, MRI is normal, and this carries a better long-term prognosis for the patient.
  • Mechanism of Injury:
    • SCIWORA is hypothesized to be related to a severe flexion-distraction injury of the cervical spine.
  • Anatomical Considerations in Pediatrics:
    • Due to ligamentous laxity in children, the spinal column can tolerate significant distraction, up to 4-5 cm, without disruption.
    • In contrast, the spinal cord can only tolerate 4-5 mm of distraction, making it more vulnerable to injury even without visible structural damage.

Reference: Campbell's Operative Orthopaedics 14th edition page number. 1548.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old woman presents to the clinic with a 6-month history of joint pain and morning stiffness. Her symptoms began insidiously, initially affecting her fingers and wrists bilaterally. She denies any trauma or recent infections. On examination, her wrists and metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joints are tender and mildly swollen. Blood tests reveal the following:

1. Anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide (Anti-CCP): Positive
2. X-rays of the hands: Periarticular osteopenia and joint space narrowing

What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?
questions.solution:
Option A - OA usually affects large joints e.g. knee joint and shows osteophytes along with joint space narrowing. MCP and wrists are typically not involved in OA

Option C - Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE): Usually presents with additional systemic features.

Option D - Gout: Typically have different patterns of joint involvement with typical pencil in cup pattern on xray.

Rheumatoid arthritis (Option B) - This patient's clinical presentation, including bilateral joint pain, prolonged morning stiffness, joint tenderness, and swelling in small joints (MCPs and wrists), along with positive anti-CCP antibodies, strongly supports a diagnosis of rheumatoid arthritis (RA). X-ray findings of periarticular osteopenia and joint space narrowing are also characteristic of RA.

Reference: J. Maheshwari's 5th Edition of Essential Orthopaedics page number. 286, 300.
